Light body with good carbonation and a semi-dry finish.

Very well made.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass dark brown, huge head. Starts intense malty, strong, a bit fruity like plums. Sourish hints. Finish with an alcoholic touch, but not too much. Well balanced finish, quite drinkable. Good one!

4/09/2011 30cl bottle @ home - BB: 11/13 (2011-431) 
Clear red brown beer, aery beige head with big bubbles, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: caramel, bread, raisins, toffee, touch of mocha. MF: lots of carbon, light to medium body. Taste: pretty sour start, ripe cherries, caramel and roasted malts, fruity characteristics. Aftertaste: still sour cherry, some mocha, little bitterness in the finish.
From a bottle in Brussles, Belgium august 2011. Amberwith a big beige head. Rosted a bit smokey aroma. Tastes sweet a bit smokey (not much).

A deep effervescent  toffee colored pour. Huge light tan head that doesnt seem to want to fade away. Plenty of lacing when it does though. Big malty aroma. Raisins, dried plums, sugar, caramel, toffee, and a slight roastiness. There is a bit of an off-aroma. A little bit on the sour note side. Taste is very nutty and malty. A bit carbonic and dry. Very nice beer. I wish they wouldve had this on tap when I was there, but the bottles will do.
Very nice dark brown color with a little red shining through, but otherwise pretty average bock.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a mahogany colour with a thick, off-white head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits and malts. Flavour of quite strong, toasted, bready malts, caramel, dark fruits and some berries. Quite thick mouthfeel and a dry, fruity, slightly warming finish. Nice one.

Bottle. Pours a nice reddish brown/copper color with a frothy mocha colored head. Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, brown sugar and some subtle hops and spice. The flavor is again very dark fruity, with a quite peppert spice, almost like in a trappist ale, along with flavors of caramel, toasted malt and nutty notes. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a pretty solid Dunkler Bock, which is wasnt expecting.

Rosy brown hues underneath a thick mat of off-white head that clings to the glass. Caramel and christmas cake aromas, glace fruit, allspice aromas. Interesting flavour in that it has an almost sour note followed by bitterness and crystalled fruits. Not bad at all, gets a good pass mark but  I was expecting a little better.
My favourite bock of 2010. Pours dark brown with tab head. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel and dark fruits. Taste is caramel and dark fruits. Very nice bock.
Colour could be a little bit darker, with more red shining through. Taste and smells very sweet, dont really like that. Nice body to it though.
Pour is attractive; aroma of sweet bock; taste surprised me as lighter than expected with some subtle earthy undertones; decent bock

33 cl bottle. Dark brown with a large tan head that lasts very well. Somewhat medicinal aroma of licorice and prunes, some bready maltiness. Flavor is fruity and sweet, with notes of nuts, licorice, caramel, wood, some earthiness. Quick finish. Medium bodied.
11.2 oz bottle. Dark reddish brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, and roasted nuts. Roasted malt character, light sweetness, with a bit of an anise/licorice note.

11.2 oz bottle.

It pours a reddish-brown with a huge, foamy off-white/tan head.

The smell is super nutty with a bit of dough, spices, caramel, and raisins.

The flavor has some roasted caramel with a nice bittersweet flavor, dark fruits, and roasted nuts.

It is a decent bockbier, and certainly interesting considering the brewery and location.
Rather interesting, a little on the sweet side, but a unique bock that stands out.
Very dark brown with a big brown head. Caramel, brown sugar, almonds, honey in a very sweet aroma. Smooth and full bodied, really nice bitter taste.

Appearance: Dark brown, hazy. Nice tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt and fruit. Dates.
Taste: Quite smooth. Dark malt and dark fruit. Slightly roasted.
Info: 330ml bottle, 26/1-2011

Bottle 33cl. 
Color: red/brown with a dark beige head. 
Aroma: Red fruit, Belgian cuberdons, sour, malt. 
Taste: Also sweet and sour of red fruit, alcohol touch. 
Aftertaste: slightly bitter. 
Texture: full, creamy

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, achetée chez Finger Lakes Beverage Center (Utica, NY). Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de petits fruits. Apparence: La couleur est brune foncée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de petits fruits avec une pointe de céréales grillées. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #3455)

Pours deep brown with an off tan two finger head. Head lasts for a while.
Little too no lacing, deep amber hue.

Aroma is sweet with mainly malt, caramel, and some sour tang.
Caramel malt and dark fruits.

Medium body, nice mouthfeel, beer is very lively with high carbonation.
Roasted malt bitterness, really spicy, and very well balanced. LaTrappe yeast signature flavor.

A nice bockbier and another great latrappe bier.
Bottle 330ml. Color dark hazy brown with big head. Aroma caramel, dark fruit, sugar. Taste sweet, alcohol, caramel, dark fruit.

33cl bottle for the brewery gift shop. Dark, hazy brown color with a stable yellowish head. Toasty malt and fruity esters in the aroma. Fruity and deeply malty flavor with dark caramel leading to a toasty and dry finish. Medium in body and just malty. A nice Dutch bok, I guess. I wouldnt doubt if they used their top-fermenting yeast for this, as its quite fruity.
330ml bottle from Utobeer, 25th August 2010. Cloudy reddish brown look. Rich malty taste. Dates, jam and a bit of candy sugar. Coats the mouth but less than expected.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 sample at http://www.lekkerstebockbier.nl/ 2010
Lots of head.  Amber colour.  Nice bok!

Shared bottle at gunnars. Pours hazy orange with a creamy orange/brown head. Rich sweet and fruity aroma with dried fruits and berries present, Alcohol even aceton whiff. Sweetness alcohol and acidity present in the mouth. Full bodied, oily and syrupy texture.

Bottle 33 cl from Amstein in St-Légier (CH). Mahogany beer with plentiful beige foam. Chocolate flavor, toffy and licorice. The taste is similar, bitter-roasted and full, chocolate and vanilla. Notes of toasted malt, candied fruits, pepper, licorice and marc. It spreads out long and drier, with hints of spices.
A great bock beer from the trappist monastery....Full of taste,just a little too sweet,but otherwise a  great beer.Little foam and full body as well as a great palate.

Bottle kindly shared by beerpal Ivar. Pours dark amber with a big creamy off-white head. Aroma of dark red fruits, plums and caramel and something like aceton. Taste is dark malts, lingering malty aftertaste. Smooth palate.
bottle from Bierkoning - Bedankt! Hazy brown colour, large off-white head. Malty base, caramel, woody hints, spicy, with raisins and caramel.

Bottle, kindly shared by my beerpal Ivar. ABV is 7%. Cloudy brown colour, big beige head with an orangey hue. Malty and slightly stale aroma (stale dark fruits). Malty rich flavour, spicy and oaky notes, moderate hops in the finish.

Bottle. Pours with a finger of lightly off-white head on a rich coppery brown, murky hue.  Raisins, toffee, and a hint of roasted malt and fruit in the aroma. Dark fruits in the flavor at first, toffee again and some reduced brown sugar, dryish malty finish.  Medium to thinner body with snappy, bubbly carbonation.  Warming, and tasty.  Certainly a solid brew.

Deep amber, reddish colour with a beige head. Malty, caramel sweet aroma with notes of bread and fruit. Malty, light roasted flavor with a fruity sweet note. Light dry and vague roasted finish with hints of alcohol.

Bottle:
Light brown foamy head that disappears slow.
Dark amber brown to almost black beer color.
Smell a mix of dark fruits, sugars, oatmeal, hints of toasted malts and iron.
Taste is light sweet and bit bitter in the beginning and gets more bitter and also dry in the end.
Taste dried dark fruits (prunes), malts, hops, grass, sugars, spices (pepper), toasty and caramel.
Dry and bitter with low carbo.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Half, Keg, The Rake. Opaque black colour with excellent lacing, hoppy aroma, some marzeppan, licorish, sweet roasted malts, leather, rich and vibrant but very grainy and not as drinkable as I had hoped.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 redish Dark brown colour with brown soft head.Smell raisins .caramel,roasted malts.Taste chocolate, roasted malts,spruce, spices,caramel.Finish, dry ,bitter, metalic,.Soft carbonation.Medium body.

Bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels. Pours a rusty brown hazy body with a creamy off-white top. Aroma is grapes, yeast, dark malts and oats. Nice. Taste is a creamy blend of tarty sour flavors mixed with light oats and caramel hints. Some cherry and wooden notes as well. Nice, but not exactly groundbreaking. Still, a well-made bock bier from a Trappist brewery with an original touch has to be accredited.

darker copper colored beer with an offwhite head. smells malty, caramelly, bittersweet. tasts of biscuits, caramel, raisins, dried pears and plums, rather sweet.
aftertaste biscuits, bittersweet

Dark brown body.
Malty arom.
Malty sweet flavor.
Lacks some Bock aspect (I cant read my notes :-).

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a tan head. The aroma is brown sugar, yeast and caramel. The flavor is dark fruit (the main fruit I get is raisins) as well as brown sugar, caramel malt, alcohol and yeast. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not bad, but not too similar to a bock. It tastes much more Belgian than German.

A Mes rate. Bottle at the Rake thanks to Carrie.Murky amber colour with a good beige head. Really pukey malt. FULL of yeast, waaaaaay over the top and sickly. Sweet malt, some caramel and nuts and a rather spicy finish with a lengthy bitterness. Far from entertaining.

from Drinks of the World - fully cloudy dark copper-red colour with a little beige foam left; nice lace; aroma of apples and caramel with notes of chocolate; medium- to full-bodied, sweet and with a quite harsh palate (use of wheat starch?), a light bitterness and an earthy malty and caramelish finish - unrefined and not much quality out there, deeply forgettable
Bottled 33cl. Nice head retention and lacework. Raisin, crackers, mushroom and banana in the nose. Not a typical bock. Sweet. Hardly any bitterness. Decent.
Pours a dark brown color with a thin brown head. Aroma of chocolate, fruits and malt. The flavor has chocolate, fruits and malt along a strong bitterness in the after-taste.

This beer pours a deep brown with a thin tan head.  The aromas are bread, light cinnamon and and a little alcohol.  The palate is slighty dry and syrupy with some spiceness in the end.  This was a great beer!  Cheers!
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malt, caramel, hop. Flavour is sweet, malt, caramel, hop, alcohol. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

Bottle, dense maple sugar brown with tight tan foam, sweet prune , raisin and 
malt aroma, flavor is leathery, dark fruit, brown sugar, toffee, lasting chocolate
finish

Bottle, from trade with jbrus. A dark reddish brown beer topped by a dense, beige head. Nutty nose with some roasted malts and a little touch of alcohol. Roasted and nutty flavor with a herbal bitterness. Warming, full.bodied and semi-dry. The flavor has a good bitterness, and some pleasant alcohol warmth, as well as some nutty maltyness. The most interesting part of this beer is that its from a Trappist brewery, but its also a fine dark bock. 100326

Pours dark with nice head. Aroma of caramel and yeast. Tastes sweet with balanced hop finish. Palate is quite yeasty. Funky and sweet with something of the cold coffee/burnt malt/stout there too. Nicely accompanied milk chocolate with roasted almond and sea salt.

huge frothy light brown head. excellent lacing. fully diminishing. muddy thick brown body. aroma: srong coffee, heavy malty, coke and fudge. if and ff: moderate bitter and light sweet; long duration. palate: medium full body, watery/oily texture, medium carbonatgion and light alcoholic and metallic finish. aquecimento alcoolico. baixa drinkability. best bock.gosto chocolate. retrogosto melado e doce de leite. estufa demais. r$38.85s
grownfools Even the postman knows whats in those packages tasting.  Bottle shared by me.  Red-brown, fine beige head.  Wheaty, burnt caramel aroma, cocoa.  Taste is cocoa, wheat, caramel.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, dark fruit, some vanilla, & toffee; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, and some spice; The finish is dry; Nicely balanced; Pretty good overall.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, molasses, plum, dates and light graininess. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, colas, molasses and plum with a smooth lingering carmel finish.

Bottle. Pours a great looking dark brown with tan head. Aroma is great, notes of malt, dark fruit, black licorice, brown sugar and spice. Flavor is very much the same, semi sweet as well with a touch of dark roasted grain and a nice burnt grain bitter. Mouth feel is medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable beer but a bit over priced.
hazy dark brown with off white head.  slightly spicy aroma with sweet malt and a little alcohol.  medium body, brown sugar and spices with a dry finish.  tasty.
dark brown coloured body with a huches off white head a spicy roasted malty aroma a spicy malty fruity herby taste with a alcholic bitter finish

Bottle thanks to Bman1113VR. Pours a dark chestnut color with a medium sized canvas head. Notes of crystalized ginger, dark brown sugar, rum / christmas cake, and raisins. Taste is chocolate, christmas cake, marbled bread, and black licorice. Mouthfeel is medium and slightly creamy.

Expensive single $6.99. Large tan head, hazed mahogony body. Molasses, Christmas cake, brown sugar, persimmons, Ginger, dried dates.  Slightly vinous. Taste is candied sugar, wheat, dark fruits, chocolate, fruit cake, rum. Lively/creamy bubbles. Some alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 30cl bottle
Dark brown color with a cloudy bubble beige head.
Lots of malts, roasted notes and some gentle hops in the nose.
Warming malts, gentle hops and a dry malty aftertaste.
Decent Bock.
Dark brown coloured beer with small white head and medium carbonation. Malty roasted aroma. A full creamy and sparkling palate. Finish is roasted malty ending bitter dry.

head: normal 
colour: dark brown almost black 
smell: candy sirup, alcohol, spices, dairy 
taste: anis, spices, coriander alcohol, black drop 
very nice !
Bottled. A hazy brown beer with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and caramel. Taste is roasted malt and yeast. Sweet. Notes of caramel and brown sugar. Slightly spiced finish.
caramel, cereal, alcohol, red, brown, tan foam, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish, bitter,

Pours deep amber, big fluffy head. Aroma is very bock-esq. Caramelly malt and disctinct yeast character with no trace of hop.
Flavour is initially slightly sweet, with caramel malts dominating. A slight roast malt bitterness follows with a nice bock yeast character.
A very well balanced, authentico bock.

750mL bottle, Trappist Tasting at Joe T.s. Pours a dark, murky, cola-brown color; creamy, thin, light-tan head with decent retention and lacing. Lots of kettle sugars, caramel, and a touch of oxidation; slightly sticky, and the dark fruit note is a bit overripe. Medium to medium-full body; relaxed carbonation, creamy texture; slight amounts of warming alcohol; a hint of fusels; medium-high levels of caramel, dark fruits, and plummy notes; slightly underattenuated, seemingly sweet, lightly sticky, minimal (minerals?) hop bitterness; light fruitiness from the yeast; just kind of bland and sticky-sweet. Lasting finish, with the appearance of a bitter chocolate notes, caramel; ~balanced ending.

Pours a murky brown with a small off-white head. Faint aroma of dark fruit and biscuit malt. Maybe some Special B. Grainy flavor with bittering hops underneath. Biscuity alcohol finish that lingers a bit. Too heavily carbonated for the style.

Bottle (in NZ). Pours a dark ruby red with a large pillowy beige head (it really is beautiful). A smoky aroma, with toffee and pine. A slightly dry palate, oak dominates the flavour, the malt just the right richness. Damn fine.

This poured a darker red color with an off white head. Aroma was grassy german hops, sweet malt and some yeast. Flavor was very odd and off, very sweet, some garbage taste and grassy hops. A german style, clashes hard with belgian character.

(bottle) pours a clear dark ruby colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of caramelized apples and dark fruit, some brown sugar, milk chocolate and yeast. flavour is the same, less subtle but nicely rounded, with dominant notes of roasted malts, dark fruit and a slightly alcoholic grainy finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.
.5L bottle - Compliments of SkyCop32. Pours a deep dark brown. Aromas of roasted malts, smoke, and hints of fruit. Flavors of the roasted malts, some fruit, with a coffee aftertaste
Poured dark hazy amber brown, dark fruit, caramel malt, yeasty, earthy, bitter finish.

Pours a very rich copper brown with a creamy lasting tan head. Excellent retention. Nose is rich and malty, some raisin, rusty grain, mild sweetness, prune. Flavor borders on thin which is unsettling given the perceived viscosity in the pour. Malty, dark candied fruits, spicy, some alcohol, estery, raisin, caramel. Palate could use some body has a mild spicy alcohol character. Interesting.
Pours dark copper with a large beige head. Aroma is bready malt, vineous and fruity. Flavour is bready malt, alcohol, vineous and fruity notes.
Bottle.  Pretty amber brownish pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma of yeast and caramel.  Great full bodied taste of brown sugar, malt, caramel and toffee with a nice even caramel finish.
malty,hoppy,red golden,clear, red head,light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, fizzy, long finish, long finish, nice beer.

Looks beautifull, amber and almost clear. Has an off-white head, fully lasting. Sweet, malty aroma. Clear yeasty notes, pepper, a bit sharp. Sweet flavor, faint acidic. Light bitter finish. Has a syrupy texture.

bottle..Cloudy deep amber pour with a dissipating tan head , some lacing . Aroma of sweet roasted malt and metal . Light caramel flavor with notes of spice from the yeast and fruit  . Dry, bitter finish with a prickly carbonation .

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber toned body with an off white head.  Malty body with dark fruit rum raisin notes, some light plum, tawny caramel and a modest warming.   A spicy tobacco and hints of roasted malts.  Sweet with a drying roasted finish.  Nice ale.

Pours a dark red color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, molasses, dark fruits and spices.  Flavors of smokey roasted malts, caramels, coffee, some drak fruits, and a hint of wood oak and spices.  Good carbonation, sweet and bitter smooth finish.  Good balance of flavors, with a nice bitter lasting taste in mouth.

Wow. I really liked this one. Poured from a bottle; a nice, rich dark-red-brown with a prominent, moussy head. Smells of molasses, chocolate malts -- and the palate is amazing; smooth, rich, and substantial, like good chai or a great milkshake. The taste is elegant; malts up front and then a close with a hoppy bitterness that cleans the palate.
Light brown coloured beer with some light carbonation and a small off-white head. Herby and malty balanced aroma. Full palate. FInish is bitter, light herby but with a rather short flavour. Not bad.

Bottle from Utobeer Market Stall. Pours brown with a red sheen, white head. Good carbonation. Very fruity nose. Cherries, toffee, caramel, herby aromas. Smokey, malty flavours with hints of toffee and summer fruits. Nice malty finish.
300 ml bottle from the supermarket a dark brown colored beer aroma of burn malts caramel and some spices taste sweetness with some spices and a bitter finish good balanced

Bottle, 33cl. Pours dark translucent mahogany, with decent slightly beige head. Sweet malts, chocolate and caramel to the nose, and similarly rich on the palate with the addition of ripe fruits. Very well balanced and blended, and overall a very quaffable Trappist beer.

Pours dark amber to red with a thick foamy to creamy head with good retention. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel and a bit alcohol. Wonderful taste that starts bitter and hoppy with sweetness and malt kicking in just a bit later, very well balanced. Finish is long, dry and bittersweet. Good carbonation and a creamy texture. Love this.

Mild but complex aroma of sweet spices, toasted nuttiness and a little warming alcohol. The flavour also has alcohol and some gentle caramel and toastedness. Warming and nicely complex but a little dull.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear mahogany beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit with notes of alcohol. The flavor is malt, sweetness and caramel. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer.

Tap 30cl trappist cup. Toasted head and brwn colour; with caramel aroma. Sweetness to the palate. From my point of view it is not a real bock but a "special" trappist beer. Easy to drink and favourable to finish the night...

(750 ml bottle (2007) from 1828 Vintage House) Pours dark clear tea-colored brown with a very tall, quickly rising tan head with each pour. Aroma of chocolate and brown sugar with Band Aid. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, lightly pebbly and maybe lightly chalky, perhaps a touch fizzy. Flavor of chocolate, light brown sugar and lightly sour, tangy red wine. Quite phenolic initially. Also kind of hot and boozy all around for just a 7% beer. This bottle may be slightly off, a little infected. Kind of a strange example of a dunkler bock, seems like there is some Belgian influence (which Im not sure is beneficial in this case).

hmmm, aroma of french crapes with strawberry jam with some alcohol through it. Head is big and uneven on a ruby red beer.
The taste is good too, but the hoppyness is a little bit too much.
bottle, kinda mahoganyish pour, some beige big bubbled foam. nose is sweet with caramel malts and dried fruits. flavor is similar , easy drinking not a ton of mouth feel but nice

Bottle. Unclear dark brown with a big, slowly-diminishing, beige head. Aroma of caramel, raisins, plums and other dark fruits. Sweet malty taste with some caramel, toastiness, some nuts, light licorice hints, dark fruits, a bit of spiciness and alcohol and metal notes. Medium-bodied.

(bottle - 330 ml) Clear brown color with a frothy tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Lots of plums and caramel up front. Flavor starts with a sweet and fruity taste mixing with some mild spice and dark malts. Theres a nice and semi-sweet cocoa middle along with some more fruits and spices. A nice yeasty finish comes up and leaves a mild sweetness.

Deep brown, slightly hazy pour with a thick tan head and some nice ruby highlights.  Really good looking beer.  The nose is fairly plummy and chewy.  A soft spicy yeast with a bit of dark sweet fruit skin.  A touch of clove and some light tannins as well.  There is a kiss of cocoa on the back.  The beer is well-balanced and eminently drinkable.  Its sweet but not cloying.  Toasty with a bit of rye-like sweetness.  A little bit rummy with a lovely sweet molasses character.  This isnt a bock, but its very good.

Dark brown colour, big creamy head, creme-coloured. Staying in the glass for a long while. In the nose there is roasted malts, coffee, caramel. Tastes hoopy, bitter, herbal, hints of coffee and malts. A bit sweet, but for sure not dominating. Long finish, Nice.
30cl, from the brewery,  complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, good Trappist

Dark chestnut with a big off-white head. Aroma of rich dried fruits, spicy phenols, alcohol and a mild oxidation. Sweet and fruity flavour with warming alcohol, and lingering malt and chocolate notes.

75cl bottle. Thanks a lot Nightfall. Trade. Pours dark browny/reddish with a small creamy white head and lacings. Sweet yeasty and malty nose. Dark fruits and caramel. A bit dusty and matured taste. Medium and smooth palate. Tasty.
It poured a hazy dark brown liquid with a small light brown foam. It had a fairly weak smell of yeast and spices. It had allot of carbonation and a taste of spices, caramell and yeast. An ok beer.

0.33L bottle, big, thick, light beige head, deep, dark brown almost opaque with just a touch of lighter brown hues. Rich malty nose with toasty hints, flavours of dark chocolate, bread,  dark fruits and hints of metal and soy. Long fruity aftertaste, medium to big body. Very good and satisying bock.
Bottle: malty, burnt caramel, coffish notes, faint smoke, some butter notes, pretty sweet with a dry finish.

Deep mahogany pour with a small, short-lived, off-white head.  The aroma is caramel, toffee, and fig with hints of anise and brown sugar.  The flavor is sweet dark fruit with some caramelized brown sugar, cinnamon, and licorice.  Sticky, medium-full body with lots of carbonation.
ambrato carico schiuma media non molto persitente note caramellate lievi tostaute frutta secca malto  in bocca caramello lievi tostaute finale leggeremnte amro un po tannica

33cl bottle from palladio, new market, rhodes city, greece.
hazy brown, large soft smooth light brown head. i spent a minute contemplating if this was a 5 or 4. nice.
aroma of cola nut, caramel, raisins.
flavor of rasted raisins (thats a first), brown sugar, dark fruits, spices, roasted grains. ends dark fruty and roasted. this dutch bock is a mix of belgian fruity bruin with the usual dutch twist, and a german dark hard roasted bock, quite an interesting mix, that, unofrtunately is more interesting than aprreciable, but still - nice try. i love to taste something new.

From bottle, amazing red to copper liquid benith a huge beige head, intense aroma of fruits like cherry liquor, prunes, with maltish tones of resembles maple syrup, nice yeasty complexity with some cheese and brandy like alcohol, flavor is less impressive than the aroma, cinnamon cookies, malt, some roastiness and bitter hoppy finish, palate is just medium. With a more powerful body it could be and outstanding beer.
Deep red colour with a huge head. The aroma is of caramel and prunes. Flavor is similar - it remind me more of a dubbel.

Reddish brown with very thick foamy head, not real clear.  Belgian candy sugar, malty, prunes, toffee nose.  Palate is sweet but a bit sharp and acidic.  Nice feel to it.  Nice tang, partially the small bubbled carbonation.  I really like this.
From bottle at The Beer Brothers Zomerbierfestival, Mechelen. Deep burgundy with a tan creamy head. Fruity with hints of nuts. On the sweet side, but good, nutty flavours. Likeable.
This dark brown beer poured with a decent beige head and a malty aroma. There is a pleasant roasted malt flavor with some carbonation and residual bitterness.

On tap at t Arendsnest, Amsterdam, 07-06-09   Pours dark amber with beige head, Aroma is strong maltiness, caramel and some yeast. Tastes of toffee, malts, dark sugars, bit nutty, nice beer.  A7 A4 A7 P3 Ov14   3.3

At La Trappe degustation facility Schaapskooi Koningshoeven I had this fine bock. Dark and malty, great bitters, modest head and carbonation. Not the sweetness that seems more and more trend in bocks. Nice beer in a nice atmosphere. I should rate this location too.

Bottle at La Trappe in SF.  Amber-brown color with a beige head.  Aroma of caramel malt, raisins and figs.  Flavor is loads of caramel malt, estery dark fruits, brown sugar, and a hint of Belgian yeast.  Smooth, syrupy, and fairly full on the palate.

tap at Arendsnest in Amsterdam - Pours dark amber with an ample head that leaves thick lacing.  The aroma is of caramel malt with a touch of dark fruit.  It tastes sweet and malty with a little of that fruit coming through.  Its medium bodied and has a slightly bitter, clean finish.  Its a great looking, very tasty bock.  Highly recommended.
rum fig & raisin  butter pudding. light lace on a brown body. slow upfront with flavor building back in the mouth.

Dark brown with a large tan head that lasts very well.  Somewhat medicinal aroma of licorice and prunes, some bready maltiness.  Flavor is fruity and sweet, with notes of nuts, licorice, caramel, wood, some earthiness.  Quick finish.  Medium bodied.  (11.2 oz bottle)
Pours a dark brown with a thick head. Aroma is of cherries, prunes, and some spice. First sip is bitter with some fruit and an unexpected dry finish. More Belgian strong than German bock.

Bottle says "Konings hoeven bock" but the link led me here. Deep, cloudy amber color with a thick and long lasting tan head. Aroma of caramel and bread. Flavor is slightly crisp with hints of apple, caramel and brown sugar with a mildly bitter finish.

Caramel on the nose and a nice deep brown colour. Taste of apples, slight tart of raspberry, spicy herbal seeds, cumin, bitterness, burnt caramel, and even a little bit of tobacco. Finish held out on a bitter note with an added spikiness.

Dark brown with reddish-orange tints. Huge, fine head. Sweet caramel aroma. Rich and malty with Belgian yeast. Malty and rich, with slightly burnt caramel and some alcohol heat. Belgian yeast quality is noticeable. More like a Belgian strong than a traditional bock
Well rounded malts and a decent Belgian quality.  Moderate brown color, somewhat standard aesthetic experience.  Not my favorite style.  Bottle label was Koningshoeven Bock.

(Bottled, BBE 06/2011, this one has the Trappist logo in it) Hazy dark ruby with a medium, tanned and firm, lasting head. Aroma of roasted, dark-bready and caramely malt. Flavor is roasted-malty, lightly sour, dryish and rye-pudding-caramely with some ashy hints. Yes, its just about as balanced and good as a Dutch-style bock can be - but I just dont get the purpose of this style...
Bottle labled Koningshoven Bock. Clear brown with red highlights and a fluffy tan head. Strong Belgian yeast citrus and dark fruit aroma and taste with a tangy bright palate.

Pours a dark amber color with a large foamy khaki head. Nose of dark fruits specifically plum and raisan. Brown sugar, clove, caramel and some spice. Initial taste of roasted malt deep in the back, sweet caramel, toffee, and plum. Mid palate continues with lightly roast creamy and hop balance. Finish is dry and short. Mouthfeel is active carbonation and light bodied. Head retention and spot lacing is excellent.

Bottle. Labeled as Koningshoeven Bock. Reddish brown body with a beige head. The aroma was full of plum, roast, tobacco, cookie dough, brown sugar and caramel. The flavor was moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. The beer finished lightly to moderately bitter and lightly sweet. It started moderately roasty but when it hit the back of the tongue, it left a sharp licorice/coffee bitterness, though nothing overpowering. Medium body with moderate to lively carbonation. Smooth texture. Much more robust and flavorful and many dunkler bocks. Very enjoyable.

Bottled, 330ml. Deep ruby with cream head. Rich malty beer but with a heavy sweetness that became cloying. Fruity, plummy, raisin with a slight butterscotch note in the background. Never really finished, just tapered off in a fruitcake type of way.

Bottle from Bottle Barn. Only $8.79 for 750. Brilliant ruby color with a massive finely bubbled tan head. Aroma of roasted caramel with some mild citrus and spice for backing. Medium body with creamy carbonation. It starts fresh mild caramel and goes to a much stronger roast, finished with some coffee? and hot spice bits. Reasonably dry, nigh astringent, ending. Its a really tasty beer.

V dark ruby, brown with a creamy thick head about one finger tall. a nice roasty aroma with barley brown sugar, caramel  elements. Tad muted though. Taste was spicier with a slight pepper and hops and malted oats.

Pours a three-finger cream/beige head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace. Deep red/mahogany color. Medium carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Malty, fruity nose. Flavor is malty, rich fruit, some caramel. No bitter aftertaste. Decent bock. $11.00 for a 750ml bottle from a Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, ME. La Trappe is not on the label anymore.

Bottle 75cl.Clear medium to dark red amber color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, nutty, prune, moderate yeasty, brown sugar notes. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081003]
Bottle. Very dark amber colored with a huge brownish head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of caramel and honey. Sweet malty taste with some chocolate and caramel. Slightly bitter finish.

Bottle 30cl.
Pours a murky copper/brown colour with a normal size head and little carbonation.
Smell is very rich, nuts there and also some spices and raisins, vaguely some fruits.
Taste is also of nuts and spices, also has the fruit there a bit more present.
Goes down very nice and warm, good bock beer.
330 ml Koningshoeven bottle. Hazy reddish brown, looks thick. In the doppelbock neighborhood with big malt, licorice, roast, some spiciness. Dry finish. The body is too spritzy for me.
Good and well brewed. It has this oxide alike aftertaste which I like, of course is not it. The aroma is like ol things but nice.

75cl bottle from Party Pak Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown to black with massive white, fluffy head that settles slowly and gracefully laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, brown sugar, toffee, candy sugar, ripe fruit. Flavor is much of the same with more prominent notes of chocolate, wood, phenol, toffee, and just a hint of coffee bitterness toward finish. Medium to full body with a slight sweet, slightly bitter finish.

Pours an amber brown with a pillowy off-white head.  Aroma is of caramel, toffee, candy sugar, and brown sugar.  Flavor is of chocolate, wood, noticeable ethers, toffee, and a hint of coffee bitterness mid-swallow.  Smooth earthy, woody flavor with a slight smokiness.  Good bock.

Tomada no teste-cego de bocks do BREJAS. Bela coloração escura, marrom avermelhada, com espuma bege densa, de média duração, deixando uma camada perene. Ótimo aroma frutado (frutas vermelhas). No sabor, notas de malte tostado e ameixas vermelhas. Final levemente seco e amargo. Corpo médio, com certa complexidade. Boa Bock.

Coloração vermelho-escura interessante. Creme medianamente denso e persistente. Aroma intenso de malte torrado. O sabor é complexo, com sugestão de ameixas, além do malte tostado e um leve álcool bem inserido no conjunto. O final é longo e tostado.
Seguramente, uma cerveja BOCK que oferece sabores e percepções além do seu estilo. Não perca.

75 cL bottle, courtesy of fonefan. Pours cloudy deep amber with a slowly collapsing tan head. Slight metallic and roasted malty aroma. Light fruity and yeasty too. Creamy prickling carbonation mouthfeel. Spiced initial flavour with a mild yeasty note. Light roasted caramel malt base. Mild mellow yeasty presence. Lingering fruity flavour into a bitter and dry spiced finish. Dry and spiced into the far finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of fonefan. Warm, dark amber golden with a fairly lively, dense beige head leaving laces. Sweetish aroma of roasted malt. Medium body with a solid base of roasted malt and pumpernickel. Some burned caramel also. Subdued bitterness. A nice straight Bock. 031008
300 ml bottle. brown colour. medium off white head. nice roasted taste. bit alcohol present.
Bottle, 7%. Seemingly clear deep red/brown colour. Big stable tan head, plasticky. Caramelly malt flavour, slightly spicy. Hint of anis. Roasted finish.

Red burgundy brown ale with a thcik moka head. A nice caramel aroma, burned toffee, and light alcohol warmth. In mouth, a sweet caramel with nice aniseed notes. Medium bodied. On tap at In de Wildeman, Nov. 2006, 2.50 Euro, 250 mL.
Bottle. Dark ruby-brown beer with a nice light tan head. Rich malty aroma with toffee and treacle. Rich caramel flavor with toffee. Medium-plus bodied. Caramel, toffee, and slight earth linger.

Bottle, 33 cl. Boutgh @ Willems. 
Clear dark brown with reddisch touch, with a creamy beige head. 
Aroma roasted malts, fruits. 
Medium body.
Taste dark fruits, bitter roasted malts, some sweet. 
Not bad.

Drinking my first (and I suspect, last) trappist bock beer from a 750ml bottle of Koningshoeven Bock -  It poured a deep, clear reddish brown body with a tall rocky beige head.  Much heavy lacing.  The aroma had cigar smoke, toast, caramel, dark stone fruit, and chocolate chip cookie dough.  The flavor delivered much the same adding only a very light herbal bitterness.  Good stuff.Binnys Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL

The first time that i taste one trappist bockbier
[Eyes] amazing creamy foam head, the color is strong and deep dark red
[nouse] Good malty, floral, sugar and hoppy aroma.
[Mouth] Good carbonation a little bitter, fresh, dry and full body.
Amen!

had as a "Koningshoeven Bock Trappist Ale".
pours a dark ruby with a very large tan bubbly head, fine lacing.
smell of some dark fruit, wheat, touch of caramel, malt in the back.
taste of tin, watery, malt, some cocoa, touch of caramel, some spice.

Clear dark reddish brown beer with a creamy beige head. Looks beautiful in its own glass. Rich aroma of raisins, roasted malts, fruits and alcohol. Flavour is raisins, dark fruits, bitter roasted malts, some sweet alcohol. Vinous and soft creamy mouthfeel. Very rich and tasteful bock.

[1312-20080419] Tap. Boozy dark banana and roasted wheat aroma. Clear, dark brown amber body with a quick foamy light tan head. Nicely roasted banana flavour with sweet fruit malt and Belgian yeast. Medium-full body. Boozy but tasty.
(@ Abbot On The Hill; Toronto, ON)

Bottle brown, 750 ml
Appearance:  Pours red to slightly deep violet body colour, typical for a Dunkler Bock beer, carbonation of body is medium, body is clear in texture, head is initially medium to big with no lacing, slowly decreasing to the minimal, off - white, cappuccino like, beige in colour.
Aroma: Plum, prune, brown sugar, light sweetness, sweet fruity but mild aroma, alcohol is well hidden, very mild flowery hoppyness, typical Dunkler Bock aroma, some Munich malts and gentle malty sweetness.
Flavour: Very interesting especially due to fact that it feels almost like a very light seassion beer in terms of alcohol content but its 7%abv! Amazing, very easy going and drinkable, some notes of malty grains, sesaonal grains, surprisingly not sweet as the aroma would suggest, plum, roasted grains, very mild bitterness, not that complex. Finish duration is medium to long, a bit too flat finish I think. Reminding Dunkel bottom fermented beer in the aftertaste, quite regular.
Palate: Body is medium, alcohol is perfectly hidden, texture is wattery. Finish feel is neutral, a bit dull, neither hints of fruits nor bitterness.

750ML Bottle. Amazing Dark Brown color, the foamy is beige and persistent one! Aroma is complex, some notes of fruits and toffee and roasted malt as well. Flavor is complex too, I could feel some chocolate, roasted malt and a lightly alcohol presence.. Mouthfeel is bitter at right point. I like it a lot!! Português : Cerveja de cor marrom escura com uma espuma bege bastante persistente, aroma é complexo com notas frutadas, caramelo e malte torrado, sabor com notas de chocolate, malte torrado e uma leve presença de álcool. Retrogosoto é amargo na medida certa. Adorei!

Bottle. [thank you, Skortila & Caesar]
Deep dark red with a rather large frothy beige-white head. Aroma is mildly sweet, some raisins and roasted caramel. Creamy mouthfeel with rather lively carbonation. Flavour is wonderful, good chocolate, raisins, sweetness. Slightly roasted and dry finish. Really a wonderful dunkler bock. Incredibly balanced, none of the sweetness of many other dunkel bocks. Wonderful!
(750ml bottle)  Pours a medium brown body with an average-sized beige head.  Aroma of mustiness, dates, and raisins.  Flavor of dark fruit, lighty toasted bread, caramel, and roasted malt.

Bottle. Creamy off-white excellent fully lasting head. Amber colour. Perfect! Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma, Orange notes. Moderate bitter flavopr. Nice complex fruity notes. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Fantastic dunkel bock.

Aroma is complex, with some caramel and a mix of roasted malt notes. The head is beige, foamy and firmly persistent. Dark brown, no bright. On flavor, the roasted malts are dominant. Medium body, some complexity. Good carbonatation, the bitterness is light to medium, well balanced with the beer. Finish is smooth. The beer is fairly well balanced, with some roasted malt aftertaste. Great beer, at the same level (but not the best) as the others from La Trappe.

Tasted at the April Northern California Beer Tasting. This bock pours a deep brown color from a 33cl bottle. Small sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel and toffee and fairly sweet. A medium bodied bock. The malts are caramel, toffee, bready and sweet. The hops are floral and earthy. Nice balance. This beer kind of surprised me, it was much better than I thought it was going to be. Its not very complex, but its very drinkable. The malts are sweet without being cloying and it finishes with a slightly dry and bitter finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

2008-04-19. Ruby tinged brown body, good sized beige head fades a bit. The signature glass is not really aiding the aroma in that it disperses it before allowing for a longer pondering of it. Teasing out the details reveals sweet malt with light toasted malt notes. (7+) Sweet malty flavour, lightly alcoholic, pleasantly warming. Malt dominant with light fruity undertones. (7+) Smooth average plus palate. Fairly pleasant, very malt forward. Nice. On tap at The Abbot On The Hill, Toronto

A clear dark red colored beer, with a very large beige foamy head. An aroma of roasted malt, caramel and toffee. There are tastes of dark fruits, some chocolate and hop bitterness. In the back its a little spicey. A very good bock beer.

Draught at The Abbot on the Hill. Rating #2200! Dark ruby-brown with a medium sized tan head that quickly recedes to a thin film. Fantastic aroma of malt, toffee, dark fruit, and a hint of spice. Full bodied without being sticky or cloying, very nice. Lovely, complex flavour - malt, caramel, brown sugar, dark dried fruit, toasted nuts - and a warm, lingering finish. Thanks to the Abbot and Premier Brands for bringing in this rare treat!

On tap @ The Abbott on the Hill, Toronto.


Heavenly malt aroma, woody, pit fruit, caramel and treacle, auburn, tiniest toffee head. Flavour is a rich candied malt, caramel, toffee, butterscotch, almonds, raisins and pit fruit. Full bodied, very well balanced, complex, sweet, bitter, silky texture, way too easy to drink. Majestic! Way to go Abbott on the  Hill!

Tapped at Abbot On the Hill.  A great haul for them. Pours an active dark brown with white crown.  Bold malt, and yeast aroma, including chocolate malt. Carbonation, natural, does not quit. In your face taste,a bit rochfort/cocacola caramel like, some nutmeg. Overall not too complex, good drinkability.

Deep chestnut body, huge lasting beige head; Pleasant but quite innocent nose with a slight acid touch; Big bubbled carbonation in a simple Trappist body with a bock touch, a bit strange; Malty a little cane sugary sweet finish, malty and fruity aromas. Drinkable but not really interesting.

Sampled during Cellars Wine & Spirits Wednesday evening beer tasting as Konings Hoeven Bock Bier. From bottle pours a clear dark copper amber brew with a moderate medium tan head that has some nice retention and sticky/spotty lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, some dry nobel hop character and a touch of dark pitted fruits. Taste is medium to full bodied, some moderate alcohol on the back-tongue with a semi-dry caramel malt flavor. Finish is semi-dry with some mild hop bitterness that quickly disappears.
[bottle] Poured a deep, cloudy brown with moderate white head. Aroma was full of caramel with some other malty flavors and tiny bit of hops. Not bad.
Nice pour of deep ruddy brown with a light tan head. Sweet and malty nose which carried into the flavor. Not very complex, but not bad.

Deep amber, reddish colour with a beige head. Malty, caramel sweet aroma with notes of bread and fruit. Malty, light roasted flavor with a fruity sweet note. Light dry and vague roasted finish with hints of alcohol.

Poured it from a large bottle with a cork. The beer was extremely carbonated and the foam built up fast. The aroma was not strong, mostly malt. The taste was sweet, moderate bitterness but the carbonation made it feel unpleasant to drink.  Didnt like it that much.

Corked and caged bottle. Large frothy, semi-fizzy tan head, fair amount of lacing, transparent, very little carbonation, and a reddish hue. The nose was malty, caramel, hint of toffee, and some fruityness. The flavor was malty, caramel, some fruityness, a light hoppiness and a dry finish.Tingly mouthfeel  and medium in body. Quaffable, easy to drink but nothing outstanding was noted.Worth a try IMO.

Bottle: Deep coppery hue with ruby highlight topped by a fading frothy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of caramel and toffee, walnut, fig, starfruit, biscuity malt and is a tad corky. The taste is simple carmelized and pale malt sweetness over a light layer of dark fruits. Almost no bitterness nor alcohol noted. Woody and nutty dry finish. The mouth feel is mild and soft. An okay brew but nothing to seek out.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a extremely large sized head of foamy finely sized light brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a transparent typically carbonated brown colored body. The aroma was malty brown malt sweet and mild hop. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a mellow hoppy aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt mild hops sweet and mild brown malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Dark copper color with a large head.  No aroma.  Literally, no aroma.  Weird, even Budweiser has an aroma.  A little yeast flavor, some bread and slight malt.  It seems like a very light bock grain bill, fermented with a Belgian yeast.
Bottle. A dark amber beer with a big beige head. The aroma and taste is of caramel malt and fruits. Medium body with a light dry finish.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 A thick, heavy head tops this dark brown beer. Strong aroma of  roasted malts. Texture is smooth and oily. Smoky, bitter flavour. Dry finish.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, hay, caramel and dried fruits.
Flavour of malts, caramel, dried fruits and hops.
Hoppy finish.
Light alcoholic.

Bottle (Koningshoeven Bock): Misty ruby, nice head and lacing. Nose of caramel, fruit (fig) and lots of bread. Burnt marshmallow afterthought. The flavor is malty with burnt sugar. Nice malty complexities throughout the flavor that just vanish in the finish. Nice drinker though.

Poured with a nice head and some lace. Very ahcoholic aroma. decent dark wood color. Not as sweet as I would expect in a bock. Give em credit for distinction though. Full mouth filling body. Slightly unpleasant bitter finish. Not one of my favorites.
A slightly lighter bockbeer than other ductch Bocks. lavour: Caramel, hop and nuts. Available from half September till March, gets better in time.

Bottle pours a medium brown, with a nice viscous flow.  Modest but lasting light tan head.  Malty and rich slightly chocolate aroma.  Some slightly ascidic notes and an overall woody lightly sweety dark malt flavor.  
Thanks Buck Dutch for sharing this one.

Bottle (30cl): Hazy, ruby-amber coloured, creamy, persistent off-white head, sticking to the glass, fruity, caramelly and toasted-malty nose with a touch of coriander and hops; moderate sweet-bitter flavour with a very little acidity, medium-bodied; sweet-fruity and roast-malty finish with a little bitterness in the aftertaste. O.K., a quite well balanced brouwsel............

Bottle:  Pours dark brown with a creamy, sand colored head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, and dark fruits.  Tastes malty, a little bready, caramel, toffee, and somewhat earthy.  Thanks BuckDuch for sharing.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, Terry! Dark brown with bright rubied highlights and slim gray rim of foam. Thick fruity pulpy sweet pitted tree fruit nose. Medium body, fizzy carb. Light and rather generically fruity mid-palate. Light finish. Surprisingly little going on here.

When rating this Im assuming that it is the same as Koningshoeven Bock.  Courtesy of Skyview.  Deep golden amber in pour with a thick foamy dirty white head.  Some spices on the nose.  Maybe some cinnamon and cloves.  A bit of malt and a slight hint of alcohol to the taste.  Otherwise it tastes much like it smells with a bit of hops and bitterness.

Bottle: Light cola in color, caramel hues, large foamy light beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Soft bready nose, very slight dark pitted 

fruit. &nbsp For a Bock it certainly smells as if its on the lighter side. &nbsp Pale breadiness on the tongue. &nbsp No soy or heavy dark 

pitted fruit. &nbsp Very light for the style. &nbsp It is somewhat of a welcomed change as I wouldnt think I could drink a 75cl of a heavy 

Bock. &nbsp Very minor fig and dates on the backside. &nbsp Certainly malty, a little mealy. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Has 

a weird aftertaste, somewhat similar to the aroma of new Tupperware. &nbsp Very faint, but its there. &nbsp Overall its decent, certainly a 

bit lighter than most, but still is somewhat flavorful. &nbsp Its also a bit airy... *BURP*.
Pours a dark brown with a nice thick creamy tan head. Aroma is fruity with a touch of yeast and malt.Taste is creamy, dry, a little bitter. A touch of roasted malt.

So Ive just booked the girlie and myself into a health resort for three days and goddamit, Ive earned a beer. The things we do for love... Shes thrilled and gushing about which "treatment" to have first while I speculate about the resorts policy on guests smuggling in beer. It would sure liven up the meditation sessions. Okay, two drinking days left, so lets get into this: La Trappe Bockbier is a handsome sonofabitch, a sparkling clear ruby-brown with a funnel of bubbles shooting from the base of the glass as if from an undersea vent. The tan head was so tall and enduring that I should have poured yesterday. It exhudes thick vinous fumes of Mirin, Christmas pudding, bubblegum, grout, shiraz and licorice. Its raw and rooty, and dominated by dark malt. Medium bodied and softly carbonated for a creamy-smooth mouthfeel. But theres nothing smooth about the flavour mix, which is down and dirty: licorice root, oak, clove, leather saddle, pepper... Its an aggressive mix with strong Christmas spice overtones. Very robust in flavour for its 7%abv. It didnt seem entirely integrated to me, but its always a pleasure to sample something as bold as this. Nice work, fellas. (30cl bottle, IBS Perth, bb March 2007)

As the Trappist brewers carefully toil amongst vats of fermenting ale, this one seems an oddity amongst the giants and yet is easily a cut above many. This was a fantastic bock, and first of the bottom fermenters, showing a little of the Dutch and, dare I say it, German influence. Honestly had the meaty consistency of a German Doppelbock along the monastic lines of Weltenburger or Andechs. Tasted from the bottle, sadly the only one I had, and poured into a shallow chalice. Deep hazy brown body with a tinge of ruby coming through in the lights. Crowned off by an amazingly dense, creamy lather of tannish foam that left a little legs. Rich and unrelenting, concentrated malt nose; bitingly spicy and reminiscent of fresh baked Xmas pudding with a zest of savoury fruits, doughy yeast and thick layers of chocolaty malts. Chewy, smooth well rounded body in the mouth; lightly spritzy carbonation tickled the front of the tongue whilst the back end had the viscosity of a fine port. A wonderful blend of strong malt and fruitcake flavours, peppery spices and zesty dried fruits and citric peels coat the mouth with a strength that belies its modest ABV. A light, earthy hop note came in late offering a meld of malt and hop bitterness before a long malty rich and lipsmackingly chocolaty swallow. Excellent balance of complex malt flavours have resulted in a wonderful Bock. One to try again. Lovely!!! (30cL, BBE 03/07, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Very good!
